ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learning about other students' experiences in STEM as well as the general challenges that STEM education faces (both in the classroom and out).
I gained a lot of insights on how different groups are marginalized and excluded from STEM. We also worked on intervention projects which was meaningful.

I learned a lot about the underrepresentation of different identities in STEM. We had weekly readings that highlighted these identities and other related topics such as helpful pedagogies to combat retention issues.
I learned how to write an op-ed, facilitate a discussion, engage with a semester-long project, and analyze underrepresentation in STEM.
I learned about the systemic issues in STEM and potential solutions for those problems.
I learned a lot about diversity in stem.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - Large breadth of topics covered.
Weaknesses - Many, many assignments. Probably could decrease the number of assignments (i.e. reading annotations and reflections were quite a number) and there were several other long-term assignments.

Strengths: Guest professors are excellent and teaching team is great - I love how teachers are really part of our learning community and it is not a top down lecture model of any kind, great material, so glad this class counts towards the MB&B Major since this is really important

Weaknesses: Not much - sometimes hard to come up with solutions given the readings but honestly I'm not sure this is a problem and I don't have any suggestions in this area - I think the intervention projects and Op-Ed are already there to help with this.

I loved that the course was project-based and didnt have exams! There was a lot of discussion both virtually and in-person so the class was very accessible. The types of assignments were varied as well which kept us busy but engaging with the material.
The class was well organized and allowed people to feel comfortable sharing their experiences. I really enjoyed the conversations and how they addressed issues in STEM in a holistic manner.
I think it could be improved by having more activities in class.

This class was set up very well for student learning. To be honest, my only complaint is that I wish we could have a longer class period for discussion. I really enjoyed the community we formed and I hope to use what we learned regarding issues in STEM to propel change within my field.
Great course I dont know any weaknesses or strengths of it just a solid class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you are interested in learning about other students' experiences and the problems in STEM. Without becoming aware of these problems, you will not be able to efficiently tackle them. Thus, I would recommend this to interested students.
Yes! Such a great addition to the MB&B Major and made me feel like a human in SMET again :)
Yes, particularly if you are a STEM student who hates tests!
Definitely!
Yes! I think this is a great class to take if you are interested in how STEM functions in society.
Absolutely, no matter your relation to STEM, this class is undeniably fascinating, and youll learn so much about the persisting issues in STEM and how to enact change with your peers.
Yes because it gets you to think and is a good class.
